titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. VI. Received a note from Mrs: Fenwick mentioning that the boxes were to be taken to the Bureau de Roulage at 11 O’Clock this morning— Mr Rumilly had called upon me yesterday to say that he should set out for London this Evening, and offering to take Letters for me— I wrote to Mr S. Williams. I called upon Mrs Fenwick between eleven and twelve O’Clock; the boxes were already gone. I reported to her Mr Bayard’s answer to the request that her son might have a passage in the Neptune— She then became urgent for means to obtain the consent of the gentlemen in England— She asked me for a Letter to Mr Gallatin, and said she should ask of Mr Erving one for Mr Crawford. I went to the Hotel of the American Legation, and to Mr Bayard’s chamber— But the physicians and Surgeons were with him, and I could not see him— I then went to Mr. Jackson and gave him the Letter for Mr Williams, to be taken by Mr Rumilly.— Mr Jackson has a letter from Mr Crawford dated at Dieppe last Friday morning when he was embarking for Brighton— I returned home and wrote to Messrs: Russell and La Farge at Havre; addressing to their care the boxes of wines I had taken of Mrs Fenwick. In the Evening I called upon her again, and gave her the Letter she had requested, for Mr Gallatin— Mrs Adams finally concluded to go with me to General La Fayette’s.— The Moniteur was brought to me this day at six in the Evening; it contains a decree of the Emperor, for an immediate election of an assembly of Representatives; who are summoned to attend at the meeting of the champ de Mai; on the 26th: of this Month.

2. V. I sent Antoine to Mr Bayard, with Mrs Fenwick’s proposal to him to take some of her wine; and the bottle as a sample, which Mr Erving had sent to me— And to the Count de Tracy’s to inform him and his family that I was going out to General La Fayette’s, and offering to take any thing they might have to send. At half past eight we left the Hotel du Nord and came out of the City by the Porte St. Antoine, and through Charenton and Gros Bois to Brie-Cómte-Robert, where we dined— We then proceeded; through Guignes, Fontenay and Rozoy, to La Grange, the General’s Seat, where we arrived between six and seven in the Evening— The distance from Paris, is fourteen leagues, and Brie is the half-way Station— The Country though generally level is in many places beautiful, and appears in fine verdure; although the fruit trees have much suffered by the late frosts; and look sickly— The roads are good as far as Fontenay. The General’s Seat is an old Castle— He is surrounded by a numerous family— His Son George and his Lady who was a daughter of Count de Tracy and they have three daughters— His two daughters—Madame de la Tour-Maubourg, and Madame de Lasterie; each with three children; among whom only one boy— The husband of Madame la Tour-Maubourg is also here— A Commandeur de La Stérieand a Mr Pillet, an old friend and fellow-Soldier, in America, of General La Fayette, who
recognized me as having seen me in the year 1796 at the Hague, where I had the good fortune to do him a good office— We dined a second time, and spent the Evening in Conversation, chiefly upon the present state of affairs in France— The General appears to be much gratified with the new decree for immediately organizing and convoking a Representative Assembly. It has probably been adopted in consequence of his advice.

3. V:45. A Gentleman of the neighbourhood a Mr de Meun was here this morning at breakfast. The General took me out to see his flocks of Merinos; of which he has a thousand, his Cattle and his horses— The house is an antient Castle, built of granit—has a centre and two wings with four turrets painted in sugar loaves— He says there is a tradition that it was built in in the time of Louis le Gros. It was heretofore surrounded by a moat with a draw bridge; but he has changed the direction of the waters into that of a winding canal— His Park was laid out by a painter in English taste and is beautifully picturesque. He has surrounded the house with trees—Poplars—willows, pines, firs, locusts, and the horse chesnut and oak at farther distance— One side of the wall at the front entrance of the house is covered from the ground to the roof with Ivy which he planted by the advice of Mr Fox who came to visit him, when he was last in France— Mr George La Fayette and Mr Pillet went this day together to Paris— Mr Meun and Mr La Tour Maubourg also went away before dinner— There was a very heavy thunder-shower at two or three in the afternoon, and steady rain all the Evening— The General gave me the last number of the Censeur to read— A periodical work, edited by two young lawyers, who after having been in violent opposition to the Bourbons, are now equally opposed to Napoleon— Quiddism, is not exclusively the growth of the American soil— The Censeur met with every possible obstacle from the Government of the Bourbons; and the present number was for several days suppressed by the Police of Napoleon— It now circulates freely, and much more extensively for the effort first made to suppress it.

4. V. There was a continual rain, the whole day, which confined us to the house. The General received the Newspapers from Paris and we had a variety of topics for political conversation— General Victor de la Tour Maubourg came on a visit, was here at dinner, and passes the Night here— He lost a leg at the battle of Leipzig. I went into the General’s library, and borrowed two or three Volumes of his books; he recommended to me a Volume of Benjamin Constant’s pamphlets; and particularly, some Observations published last Summer, on a Speech made by the Abbe de Montesquieu then Minister of the Interior, to the Legislative Assembly, on the Law then projected relating to the Liberty of the Press— Constant, who was then one of the most furious adversaries of Napoleon, and continued to be so until the 19th. of last Month, when he published a frantic Article against him in the Journal des Débats, is now one of his Councillors of State— He is, as I heard him say at Madame de Stael’s dinner, essentially a pamphleteer— He writes with some ability, and it required very little to refute the contemptible sophistry of the Abbe de Montesquieu— But in his pamphlets as in his conduct, Benjamin Constant shews continual indications of an unsettled head— He has the merit of having been invariably a friend of liberty.

5. VI. We breakfasted at Nine O’Clock— Two hours earlier than the General’s usual time— But it was for the sake of enabling us to depart in seasonable time to arrive before the Night at Paris— We took leave of the General and his family just at ten; and returned by the same road that we had gone, excepting that we joined the high-road without passing through the town of Rozoy. We reached Brie at half-past two, and dined at La Grace de Dieu— When we went down we had dined at the sign of L’Esperance— We changed the house by the recommendations at the General’s, but the house which we first went to was the best. At four we left Brie, and just at eight in the Evening alighted at our lodgings. Hotel du Nord, Rue de Richelieu— The weather was all day fair, with the exception of a light shower in the afternoon— On my arrival home I found two Cards from Mr Bayard, which he had left this day— Letters from Messieurs Meyer and Brüxner and Harris; and the Newspapers of the last four days, which engaged my attention the remainder of the Evening. Our visit to La Grange has been agreeable, although the weather was bad, and confined us to the house almost the whole time we were there— The General himself is always cheerful, and of pleasant conversation— And the family though some of them in circumstances at present uneasy, are amiable and attentive to their guests— The two Sons in Law, La-Tour Maubourg and La Stérie were both officers of the guards of Louis 18. and had both a sort of injunction to reside not within 30 leagues of Paris— General La Tour Maubourg is an elder brother of the Son in Law.— He is a man of simple, unpretending manners, but in his conversation now very cautious and reserved— Genl. La Fayette told me that he should go next Monday to the meeting of the electoral College of the department of Melun.

6. VI. I sent, this morning to enquire if it was Mr Bayard’s intention to leave Paris this day, and was answered that he would go, at eleven this Morning— I called upon him about that hour, and found him preparing for his departure— The horses were already there— Mr Todd was with him. Mr Daniel Parker came and took leave of him while I was there. Mr Bayard had received a letter of 28 April from Mr Clay, and
Letters of the same date from Mr Clay and Mr Gallatin, to Mr Crawford had been received and opened by Mr Jackson— Mr Clay observed that he had not succeeded in obtaining a passage to the United States from Liverpool, and should wait for the Neptune.— Mr Gallatin expresses also the positive intention of returning to America in the Neptune. But they had already had one or two interviews with Lord Castlereagh relative to the Negotiation of a Treaty of Commerce, and were to have another with him, the President of the board of Trade, and third person, to see if they could agree upon the bases of a Treaty. Mr Clay however appears not to expect that they would come to any result, and is anxious to return home as soon as possible— After taking leave of Mr Bayard, I called upon Mr Jackson, who shewed me the Letters from Mr Gallatin and Mr Clay, to Mr Crawford— He had also two Letters enclosed from Mr Gallatin, to Mr George La Fayette, which I took and carried with me to the Count de Tracy’s— I left the Letters with him to be forwarded, as Mr La Fayette returned yesterday to La Grange— I had some Conversation with Mr: de Tracy, on the present state of affairs in France— War appears now to be certain, which the allies will profess to wage only against Napoleon Buonaparte— The first thought and object of the inhabitants of Paris will be to save themselves— They have no attachment either to the Bourbons or to Napoleon; they will submit quietly to the victorious party, and will do nothing in support of either— If the same Spirit should prevail throughout France, Napoleon will be soon overthrown— As I walked to the Tuileries and through the Palais-Royal before dinner I saw a multitude of pamphlets against the projected supplement to the Constitution. The Caricatures as yet are all of one side— We went this Evening to the Cirque Olympique of the Franconis— Exercises of Horsemanship—the Cerf Coco—and a Pantomime called Le Pic Terrible.

7. VI:15. Mr F. Williams called upon me this morning, with Mr Boott from Boston— He left London last Wednesday Morning, and brought me a Letter of the preceding day, the second of this Month, from Mr Beasley, enclosing a despatch from the Secretary of State dated 13th: March, and which though not marked as such must be a duplicate— It informs me that I was appointed Minister Plenipotentiary to Great-Britain, and mentions the enclosure of a Commission and Credentials; neither of which however was enclosed— We had a visit from Mr Todd, and Mr Carter— Mr Bayard left Paris yesterday, between one and two O’Clock in the afternoon— Milligan went with him. Mr Todd intends to go, on Tuesday Morning.— I wrote to my Mother, and took a short walk before dinner— Napoleon was reviewing troops in the yard of the Tuileries— The cries of Vive l’Empereur, and à Bas les Royalistes were frequent in the Streets the whole day. The crowds of people in the public walks, unusually great.— Evening at the Odeon— J’ai perdu mon procés— Une Journée à Versailles, and Le Portrait de Michel Cervantes— The Journée à Versailles is a good comedy— The rest was trash. On returning home I found a Card of Mr J. N. D’Arcy of Baltimore, with two Letters from Mr Beasley of 3. May—one of them enclosing a Passport for me and my family from Lord Castlereagh— Mr D’Arcy is to call upon me again to-morrow Morning.

8. VI. Mr D’Arcy paid me this morning a visit with Mr Todd. I was mistaken in the expectation that he had dispatches for me from America— He lent me several English Newspapers of the 3d: instant, and sent me a number, of Cobbett’s Register, and one, of the Edinburg Review. Mr Todd told me he should not leave the City until to-morrow Evening.— I wrote part of a Letter to the Secretary of State. On returning from a walk before dinner with Charles I received by the Post, a Letter from Messrs: Baring, Brothers, at London, informing me that they had received from the American Department of State a packet for me, enclosing my Commission, and Credentials to Great Britain, which they are directed to retain until my arrival in England— Their Letter is of the 2d: instant— I determined to proceed to England with as little delay as possible. In the Evening I gave permission to Charles to go with Antoine, and see the Rope-dancers— Mrs Adams and I went to the Odeon, and saw La Molinare— Porto and Madame Morandi performed their parts well— The rest were worse than indifferent.

9. VI:15. I determined to hasten my departure from Paris, so as to reach the Havre, if possible next Monday; and to take passage for England in the Neptune, if she should be detained until that time— I made up my packets to go by Mr Todd; called at his lodgings, at the Hotel de l’Empire, and delivered them to him— I wrote by him to Captain Jones, and to Messrs Russell and La Farge— I requested Mr Todd, to write to me from Havre, both to this place, and to Rouen; to inform me, if the vessel should be detained so that we can go in her. He promised me that he would— I met Mr Hasler at his lodgings; who is yet of opinion that there will be no war— After I returned home Mr Beale called upon me with a Letter for his father, which he wished to send by Mr Todd— He left it with me.— I walked out an hour before dinner, and met Mr Todd who was just going to take his seat in the Diligence for the Havre— I wrote to the Duke de Vicence, Minister of foreign Affairs, to ask for a Passport, and an interview with him to take leave— Evening at the Theatre des Varietés—Le Valet Ventriloque, La Ferme et Le Chateau—Les deux Magots de la Chine, and Le petit Enfant prodigue— They are all farces of the lowest kind; but the performers are better of their kind than are to be seen at any other Theatre in Paris—Brunet, Potier, Fercelin, Bosquier Gavandan, are all excellent actors— Potier, equal if not superior to any actor of farces that I ever saw.

10. VI:15. I wrote by the Post to Mr Beasley, and to Messrs: Baring Brothers and Co:— London— Visit from Mr Copeland— Also from Mr Jackson, the Chargé d’Affaires, who came to enquire if I could certify that Mrs Custis, formerly Mrs Law, the Grand-daughter of General Washington’s Lady—has a fortune equal to 120000 francs— A French Officer, Colonel De Greffe if engaged to marry her— But to obtain the Emperor’s consent he is required to produce proof that she has an Estate of that value— Coll: De Greffe wrote to Mr: Jackson requesting such a certificate, and also that he would not mention that she was divorced, as that would also prevent him from obtaining the Emperor’s consent— Mr Jackson asked me, if I could testify to the fact of Mrs Custis’s fortune— I could not. I went with Mrs Adams, and paid a visit to Mr and Mrs Hottinguer— Mr Hottinguer is chosen a member of the House of Representatives, to be assembled with the Champ de Mai, the 26th. of this Month— We afterwards went to Ravrio’s—the shop where the fine bronzes are sold; and made some purchases; to be packed up and sent by the Diligence to Havre— Evening with Mrs Adams at the Theatre François, Andromaque and La suite d’un Bal Masqué— Talma was admirable in Oreste— Every other part in the Tragedy was below mediocrity. The Comedy was well performed in all its parts— Mlle: Mars and Mlle: Le Verd are always good— Armand the same. Michelot was this Evening much better than usual— The degeneracy of this Theatre in Tragedy is unquestionable— In Comedy they approach nearer to the antient standard— Received an Answer from the Duke de Vicence to my Note— He will call to see me to-morrow.

11. VI:30. All the morning we were engaged in making preparations for our departure— Mr Petry called upon us with news, which proved to be only a groundless rumour. The Duc de Vicence called immediately afterwards, and told me that the firing of the Cannon, had been for a visit which the Emperor was making to the hospital of Invalids.— He mentioned to me many circumstances relating to the state of public affairs at this time, and said that they were perfectly informed of all the proceedings of the Congress until after the Emperor arrived in Paris.— That six dispatches from Talleyrand to the Ministry of Louis 18 had been received by him the Duke de Vicence since he came to the Department of foreign affairs— They had the whole history, of the Declaration of 13. March, and knew by whom it was written— That Talleyrand obtained the signatures to it— That it was signed first by Prince Metternich, who was un homme très leger; and who scarcely took the trouble of reading it, and never thought of reflecting a moment upon its meaning— The Duke of Wellington signed it in the same manner— The rest signed upon trust— The Duke said it was amusing to be told that Lord Wellington had been highly indignant at learning that he was charged as an instigator of assassination for having signed that declaration— The truth was he had signed it, without knowing what it meant—impelled by a moment of passion— It was a declaration signalizing one individual as a wolf, not entitled to any of the privileges of a human being.— They thought that by using high-sounding and bitter words they alone would suffice to destroy him— At the same time they thought his undertaking so weak and insignificant, that they actually wrote here that two brigades of Gensdarmes would be more than enough to put him down— I told the Duke that I had seen a remark in the Edinburg Review, that if the mere facts of the Emperor’s landing and resumption of the Government of France were put into a Romance, they would be rejected as too improbable for a narrative of fiction— He said it was true, but he could assure me there had been no previous concert between the Emperor and any person here— Not a human being in France knew that he was coming— The Duke saw by a smile on my countenance that I was not altogether credulous of this fact, and said—eh bien!—remember what I now say to you— Depend upon it the fact will ultimately be known and proved— I repeat that there was not a human being in France, who knew of the Emperor’s design, before he landed— I told him what was said in the Edinburg Review of a watch word of La Violette and elle reviendra au printems— He said there was nothing in it. That Le Pere la Violette was a name the Soldiers had given the Emperor among themselves, as they had formerly called him le petit Caporal.— But there was nothing of plot or conspiracy in it— As for himself when he first heard that the Emperor had landed, he did not believe it. He had been a whole day disbelieving it, until it was ascertained to him by a general who had received it directly from General Maison. The Emperor knew, however, the universal discontent, and disgust at the Government of the Bourbons in France— He received the newspapers; but during the whole time that he had been at the Island of Elba, only two persons had been from France to see him. But the Bourbons were so odious that if the Emperor had not come, there would nevertheless have been within two Months a Revolution against them— They knew it very well— All the Correspondence from the interior, as well as that to and from Vienna, which had fallen into the hands of the present government, shewed that Louis 18. himself saw the impossibility of getting along.— The Duke told me that if this change had not taken place he should himself have gone to America— He had made all his arrangements for going this Spring. He could not have lived in France— The Emperor of Russia had kindly given him an invitation to Russia, but he had not chosen to accept it, and had formed the settled determination to go to America— He said also that the Emperor of Russia had spoken to him here at Paris, with great disapprobation of the Bourbons and their proceedings—and said they risked every thing as
they were going on— He further said that since he had been in the Department they had received three dispatches from the Count de Noailles, the Ambassador of Louis 18 at St. Petersburg. That the Count complained that he found himself embarrassed in Society because he heard opinions expressed very freely against the war— When the Duke left me he said he should send me a despatch to be forwarded to Mr Serrurier, the French Minister in the United States; to whom new Credentials had been sent, and who was understood to have given general satisfaction in America— We had also a visit from Mr Boyd.— In the Evening we paid a visit at the Count de Tracy’s to take leave— The Count himself was abroad— We saw Madame de Tracy and Mr and Madame de l’Aubépin— They told us that General La Fayette was elected a member of the Representative Assembly— And had been President of the electoral college at Melun. That the General would be in Paris next Saturday to dine— I had determined to leave Paris at 4 O’Clock afternoon, on Saturday.— But having a strong wish to see the General, before I go, I now concluded to postpone our departure until the next Morning. The Ladies and Mr: de l’Aubepin, made many enquiries as to the manner of living in America. This family too has had, and perhaps may have again the project of removing to America— After our visit we finished our Evening by a walk upon the Boulevards.

12. VI. We were engaged all the morning again, in packing trunks to send away by the diligence to Havre— It was almost four in the afternoon, before I could go out of the house— We dispatched nine Trunks and boxes, by the Diligence which went this afternoon— I called and took leave of the Duke de Vicence, whom I found dressed, ready to go with his Porte-feuille, à l’Elysée— My visit was accordingly very short, in which however we had some further interesting conversation.— He said that he had asked Mr Petry to call upon me with my Passport, and the Despatch for Mr Serrurier— That Petry had been long in America, and wished to return there again— He was a very good man, and he, the Duke should do for him what he could— I asked him if there was any foundation in the rumour that the king of Naples (Murat) had beaten the Austrians— He said there was no authentic account of it— But many private letters mentioned it with confidence— The Minister of the Police had received one yesterday, and he himself had one this Morning— I observed that the public funds had risen here considerably within these few days— That there must be some foundation for it in circumstances not generally known— He said there had been some symptoms of hesitation in Austria to join in the latest projected measures of the allies— That there had been since the Treaty of 25 March a further declaration, proposed and actually signed by three persons— He had the declaration itself— Austria had, it seemed, declined signing it— There was also understood to be some discordance in the English Cabinet— Lord Liverpool was understood to be inclined to continue at peace— Lord Castlereagh was ardent for War— I asked if he was certain of this— He said he had reason to believe it. He knew at least that Lord Liverpool had been so earnest for the Peace with America that he had tendered his resignation to the Prince Regent, if it was not made— Lord Castlereagh was for continuing the War— I said that we knew perfectly well what were Lord Castlereagh’s dispositions when he passed through Ghent on his way to Vienna— But we had heard, that from Vienna, he had written home, advising that they should conclude with us.— He said that was true— It was in consequence of the discussions with Russia, and with Prussia, respecting Poland, and Saxony. Lord Castlereagh was then much at variance with the Emperor of Russia, and did write to advise the Peace with America— All this was fully disclosed in the Correspondence from the French Ambassadors at Vienna, with his department, and was now among the archives.— After leaving the Duke, I paid visits to Messrs: Barnet, D. Parker. Appleton, and Warden— The last of them has changed his lodgings— The others were out, or at dinner— Evening at the Opera Comique, Rue Feydeau—Le Billet de Lotterie, Les deux Jaloux and Les Visitandines. The house was tolerably filled— Madame Duret and Madame Gavandan were the best of the performers— I had this morning also a long-visit from Mr Erving.— I asked him if he did not think Austria was practising an imposition upon Napoleon? I am much inclined to think so myself— A Mr Lannuier brother of our Landlord and Maitre d’Hotel at Ghent, came and asked me to recommend him to Mr Jackson for a Passport as an American to go to Ghent— He is not an American, but has been settled ten or twelve years at New-York, and has a wife and two children there— He came from New-York last winter, and brought with him one of his Sons, whom he sent to his brother at Ghent— But the boy not being satisfied with his situation there he intends taking him back to America, with him and wants to go to Ghent for that purpose— I hinted to him the difficulties which would naturally be made here to giving Passports for any person to go to Ghent, the present abode of Louis 18. and the solid objection against giving him, who professed not to be an American, a Passport styling him such. I promised to state his case to Mr Jackson, but said that I should in his situation not give a Passport.

13. VI:15. Before breakfast, I received from Mr Hottinguer a Note, stating that he had just received a Letter from his house at Havre, with the information was carried on board of the Neptune, the day before yesterday, almost dying, and that the vessel was sailing. It is therefore unnecessary for me to precipitate my departure, and I concluded to wait a day or two longer— Mr Hottinguer likewise sent me American Newspapers, from New-York to 31. March— We had heard at Count de Tracy’s, that Lord Kinaird was in Paris— I sent to his lodgings to enquire when I could see him, and was answered this morning at eleven— I went and renewed the old acquaintance I had had with him at Berlin.
He left London, the third of this month, and says that in England they are entirely misinformed of the state of things here. He thinks that Napoleon will prove too strong for the allies, and that the war against him is unwise— I had an hour’s conversation with him, and he appears to consider the situation of the Emperor in its most favourable light. He mentioned the forged Letters lately produced by Lord Castlereagh in Parliament, against Murat, and told me that he was going to see the original Letters themselves— He said he should call upon me to see Mrs Adams, and offered me a seat in his box at the French theatre— But I was so much engaged for this Evening that I could not go— I paid visits to Mr Jackson, our Chargé d’Affaires, at his lodgings, Rue des trois freres, N. 13. to Messrs: Copeland, F. Williams and Boott—in the Place Vendôme— I spoke to Mr Jackson, of the application from Lannuier; he said he had refused him a Passport to go to Ghent; but had offered him one to go to America— I gave Mr Copeland an order upon Mr Lewis at St: Petersburg for the box belonging to Mr De Grand— After I came home I had visits from Mr: Parker, Mr Appleton and Mr Barnet, which kept me engaged until the time for dinner— I received Letters from Mr Todd, and from Messrs: Russell and La Farge at Havre, informing me that the Neptune sailed the day before yesterday— I sent to Count de Tracy’s to enquire if General La Fayette had arrived, and learned that he had— Went in the Evening to see him, but he was gone out. We went also this Evening to several shops for Articles of dress and furniture which will be necessary for us.

14. VI:15. We walked out this morning on the Boulevards to see the procession of the Confederates of the fauxbourgs St: Antoine and St Marceau and saw them pass— They were going to the Tuileries to be presented to the Emperor— There were about 3500 men and boys of the Fauxbourg St: Antoine, and 1600 of Fauxbourg St Marceau— All Labourers of the most indigent Class. They marched in ranks of 20 holding one another arm in arm, and shouting incessantly vive l’Empereur— After returning I went and paid visits to take leave at Mr Hottinguer’s. Mr Hubbard’s and Messrs: Carrette and Minguet’s— We then went to the Champ de Mars, and saw the buildings preparing for the Assembly of the Champ de Mai— Thence to the Garden of the Tuileries, through which we walked, and the Place du Carousel to the Musee Napoleon, where we entered and took a final view of the Antique Statues and Marbles on the ground floor— We came home and dined; after which we rode out to the heights of Montmartre where the entrenchments for the defence of Paris are now carrying on— As we returned home we stopped at the Count de Tracy’s, where we saw the Ladies, and General La Fayette. The Count himself was gone out.— The General promised he would call at my lodgings, and see me, to-morrow Evening at seven O’Clock. He said he was glad of having been elected a member of the Assembly of Representatives; because it gave him a reason for declining to be one of the Peers, as had been proposed to him— I said that if the War should take place as appeared inevitable, I intreated him to use his influence to prevent the repetition of such outrageous acts as the decrees of Berlin, & of Milan—for if such measures should be resorted to I really believed they would produce a War, between the United States & France— He promised me to use his best endeavours to promote a just and liberal policy towards America and said he would correspond with me through the channel of our Chargé d’Affaires Mr Jackson— He said he had seen this morning Mr Constant, who was quite uneasy, under the situation in which he has placed himself, and who has become an admirer of the Emperor Napoleon.

15. VI:15. Still preparing for our departure, and determined to go by the way of Havre, on account of our baggage, which is there. I wrote to Messrs: Russell and La Farge— Went with Charles and saw the Mint, and the Monnoie des Médailles— There was scarcely any thing doing there, and the whole establishment is inferior to that of St: Petersburg. There is one steam engine, much out of order. The only place where they were at work was one apartment, where they were striking five frank pieces— The cabinet of minerals I had not time to see— The Medals are in another house, and are the same that I had seen at Ghent. I called at the Hotel des Affaires Etrangères, to see Mr Petry, but he was not there— I called at Mr Warden’s and left a Card. Procured a Kilogramme in the Rue de la ferronerie; and exchanged some money for Bank Notes and Napoleons, at a shop in the Palais Royal.— On returning home I found that Lord Kinnaird, and Mr Warden had paid visits— Madame de Tracy had also been to see Mrs Adams. General La Fayette came in the Evening; and I renewed the request to him to use his influence, if the war should break out, to maintain a system of moderation towards the United States; even if a different example should be shewn by Great-Britain.— He said that he had seen Joseph this Morning, and he had again urged upon him to consent to be one of the new House of Peers— He had answered, that having been elected one of the members of the Representative chamber, he was under an obligation at least to begin by taking his seat there— Afterwards he might with more propriety see what was to be done— Lucian had also sent him a flattering message by Humboldt— Joseph had asked him why he had not been to visit the Emperor; and had complained of the conduct of certain Senators, in voting the décheance— He had answered that as a member of the Assembly there would naturally be relations between the Emperor and him, which would make a visit suitable— That as to the déchéance, he should not disguise that if he had been a Senator, he should have voted for it himself— The Emperor had made of the Senate Conservateur, a Senate Destructeur; and after having to please him destroyed every thing else, it was no wonder they should have finished by destroying him— It was now said he came with an
entirely different system, and that he was to govern upon liberal and patriotic principles; which was very well— The General added that he thought it best to keep upon the reserve, because he thought he saw a wish to entangle him in connection with them, before the meeting of the Assembly— He said that as the most important object was to prevent the enemy from giving the Law to France, he should be for furnishing the Government, perhaps without acknowledging Napoleon as Emperor, with the means of carrying on the War successfully, and then to form the Assembly into a constituent Assembly, and make a new Constitution— He thought Napoleon’s great object would be to obtain those means, and then to go immediately and fight a Battle— He said Joseph had told him there were some pacific overtures from Austria; which amounted only to this, that if he would sanction not only the Treaty of Paris, but the measures of the Congress at Vienna, concerning Poland, Saxony and Italy, his wife and child should be restored to him— Joseph said this proposal would not be accepted, for it was itself shameful to put such an act upon such a Condition, and even if it should be accepted Austria would probably break the bargain, and still keep the wife and child— On the whole I see that La Fayette is fluctuating in his own mind— He asked me if I should see the Duke of Orleans in England— I did not know— He asked me, what I thought the allies would do, if any thing should happen to Napoleon—for instance if he should be killed in Battle—whether they would force the Bourbons upon France— I thought they would leave France as free as they had last Spring— He wants Napoleon, as a military Commander, to defend the Country, and yet fears the consequences of his success— He thinks much of the Duke of Orleans— Much of a Republic— And he would be glad to have a last resort even if Louis 18 should come back. At bottom there is an ardent love of his Country, and a sincere desire that it should be governed by a free and liberal Constitution; but with regard to the means he has nothing settled, and waits for Events— Especially for the meeting of the Assembly. He asked me to tell them in England that they were acting against their own views, by commencing this War— Another person said to me, that if Napoleon should not throw himself into the arms of the People; j’espere qu’au Mois prochain on le fera sauter— La Fayette has no positive design of this kind— He is balancing, and I fear that his scale will not preponderate at the lucky moment. He renewed the promise of corresponding with me; and asked me to take some Letters from him for America.

16. V. Began the day by bringing up the arrears of my Journal, at which it is generally inconvenient to write, in traveling. The remainder of the morning was occupied with the last preparations for departure. Mr Erving and General La Fayette came and took leave of us, and Mr R. Boyd, saw us into the Carriage— I went to Mr Hottinguer’s and settled my accounts with him taking a small bill upon Havre and one upon London— We received a multitude of Letters and packages from several persons to be carried to England. With our large quantity of baggage they encumber us not a little. We had ordered the horses at 3. O’Clock in the afternoon— They came at half past three, and at twenty minutes past four, we left the Hotel du Nord, Rue de Richelieu N. 97. where I have passed upwards three months, of leisure, too unprofitably for any useful purpose, but as agreeably as any part of my life. We travelled three stages, and arrived at Pontoise between 7 and 8. We stopped to lodge at the Hotel du Juste, and ordered horses for three O’Clock to-morrow Morning.— My object in coming thus far this day was to have an easy day’s ride to reach Rouen to-morrow. But we find the roads so good, and the days are now so long, that we might easily have gone two Stages farther this Evening, and have reached Havre itself to-morrow Night— The Country is in its early verdure, and the orchards are all in full blossom— We had green pease this day for the first time at dinner, and within these two days have seen small bunches of cherries for sale in the Streets.

17. III. But it was half past four when our Post-horses came— We travelled with excellent roads, and reached Rouen at half past One O’Clock in the afternoon. The distance is 11 1/2 Posts— The face of the Country very much like that between Paris and Pontoise. Covered with Orchards, all in full blossom— There are some fields of grain, and some of pasturage; here and there a flock of sheep; but the grounds are much inferior in fertility to those of Flanders, and approaching towards Rouen, the Country becomes mountainous. The City of Rouen is in a deep valley, between two steep and lofty hills. The Seine is not wider than at Paris. The Streets are all so narrow that it is scarcely possible for two Carriages to pass each other in many of them— We stopped to dine at the Hotel de Vatel, Rue des Carmes, and were detained there three hours; waiting more than half the time for horses— We heard frequent cries of Vive l’Empereur as we left Paris, and until Pontoise— But this day very few, and confined entirely to small children.— We came from Rouen two Stages to Yvetot, and stopped there to lodge— Thought it was between seven and eight, and scarcely Sunset when we arrived there. Mrs Adams was much overcome with fatigue— We have been several times obliged to repair our wheels, and they are yet in so crazy a state, that I do not incline to travel with them in the Night.

18. III:15. Though our horses were ordered for four O’Clock, it was five before they came, and we proceeded immediately from Yvetot. We had 6 1/4 Posts to Havre, where we arrived at 11 in the Morning. We might easily have arrived here last Evening, by coming two Stages further the day we left Paris, and not stopping at Rouen to dine— But the gates of Havre are shut at ten, in the Evening; after which no person is admitted into the City in the Night— We stopped at the Hotel des Armes de la Ville du
Havre, to which we had been recommended by the Innkeeper at Rouen— As soon as we had alighted from the Carriage, and got settled in our chambers, I went to find out the residence of Messrs: Russell and La Farge— I soon found Mr Russell, and to my great disappointment learnt that there was no packet here bound to England— There was a Mr Remsen of New-York with Mr Russell, who is going to England, and looking out for a passage— We all went to the English Hotel and Coffee house, frequented by the Masters of the Packets, and were told that a Packet was expected to-morrow unless the Communication should have been stopped, as was generally expected in England. There was a Portsmouth Newspaper of the 15th. in which was an Article from London stating that the Declaration of War against France was to appear in the next Tuesday’s Gazette— The Packets which used to pass regularly between Southampton and this place have ceased coming for several weeks— I had thus the prospect of being obliged to go to Dieppe for a passage, and the uncertainty whether we can obtain one even there— I went to the house of Mr Hottinguer, the partner of which is a Mr Bourlet, and delivered the Letter which I had received from Mr Hottinguer for them— They, as well as Mr Russell promised to make enquiries to ascertain if a passage can be procured, and in the Evening Mr Bourlet send me word there was a small French Sloop, the Master of which would engage to take us over; and Mr Russell called upon me, with information that there was a Danish ship just arrived from London, now unlading, and which was to sail again for London next Monday.— To-morrow Morning I shall have further information concerning these opportunities— There was a small boat, which sailed this afternoon, with a lading of Oats, we went to see her at the wharf; but it was impossible to think of going in such a thing with a family— Mr Remsen did not choose to go in her, alone— Mr Judah Hays called on me this Evening with Mr Russell.

p.hi: Itinerary of the Journey from Paris to Havre.

div.p: The general reckoning in traveling with Post Horses throughout France is that you must allow one Post for an hour, At this Season of the year, the roads being at the best, the days at the longest, and the weather at the most moderate you may by extraordinary diligence travel 5 Post in 4 hours; or at the rate of one Post and a quarter by the hour— They are from ten to fifteen minutes in changing horses at each Stage— If you go however to an Inn, and order horses at a particular hour you have to wait an hour longer before they come— We were detained three hours at Rouen, merely by stopping to dine— The Stages are all very short— A Post is two leagues; but the leagues are of 25 to a degree, and where the roads are mountainous they make allowance for it upon the distance— I think Paris and Havre as far from each other as New-York and Philadelphia; and not more. They travel much more at present by the Diligences and public Stages, than with Post-horses. On the whole road we did not meet a single carriage traveling Post— We met at least twenty Stages— Mr Todd came from Paris, himself in one Carriage, and sent his baggage in another— He arrived before the Neptune sailed: but his baggage did not. He was obliged therefore to wait, and went over in a packet which sailed the same day, to Southampton.

19. VI:30. Had a restless and uneasy Night, owing to a bed with damp sheets— The Captain of the French sloop recommended to me by Mr Bourlet, to take passage with for England came, and I went with him to look at his vessel— The tide was out, and she lay aground so that I could not go on board. The vessel is very small; carrying only 32 tons, and the Captain offered to take us, with all our
baggage, and our Carriage, for 25 louis. I was to go again at 4 in the afternoon when the tide would be high, and look at the Cabin— I went to the Lieutenant Extraordinaire de Police, and received back from him my Passport which had been taken at the gate— He told me there was no esprit public here; and that if all the Departments of France were like this, tout serait bientot fini. Mr Russell called upon me with Mr Green and Mr Remsen— We went on board the Danish vessel bound to London— It is a ship of between two and three hundred tons, and is to sail next Monday— The Captain was not on board; but the Mate took my name and address, to give to the Captain, with the request that he would call upon me— Afterwards came the Captain of the other vessel, the Sloop, Confiance, requesting me to decide immediately whether I would go with him or not; as he had now an offer, for taking freight to Rouen. I told him that I could not determine immediately; and would not deprive him of the opportunity of taking his freight to Rouen— Mr Bourlet also paid me a visit— We dined with Mr Russell; but Charles who has found two boys, with whom he has formed an acquaintance, desired to be excused, and I complied with his wish— Messrs: Hays, Green and Remsen dined with us at Mr Russell. In returning home from Mr Russell’s, we went on board the Danish vessel— The Captain was not there; but a friend of his was; and also the Consignee of the vessel— The friend intimated to us, that he believed the Captain could not spare either of his state-rooms; upon which with some vivacity, I expressed the determination to look out elsewhere for a passage. They at last promised that the Captain should call upon me at eight to-morrow Morning.

20. VI. The Captain of the Danish vessel came to me this Morning at eight O’Clock, and I immediately found the motive for his reluctance to resign his state-room. He asked me 200 francs for the passage of each person of my family, and 25 louis for my baggage. He finally consented to take two pounds Sterling per Ton, for my baggage, and I offered him 600 franks for a passage for my family— We came to no final determination— I went to Mr Russells, and with him and Mr Remsen called upon Mr Green— This Gentleman has established a commercial house here, with Mr Samuel Welles & Mr F. Williams. I made further enquiries for an opportunity to go to England— The Captain of the French Sloop whom I had seen yesterday sent again to propose taking us, and Mr Green brought another French Captain who had a Sloop at Honfleur, and was also willing to go with us.— I went again to the London Tavern and Coffee-House, and enquired if the Flying Fish, Lord Nugent’s Yacht which was to have arrived yesterday, was yet here— They told me that the price for a passage in her was six guineas for each person; and no discrimination made for Servants or children— In the regular packets the price is two guineas for each person— After dinner I walked out with Mrs Adams, and we ascended the hill nearest to the City; from which we saw the City, the neighbouring Country, the River and the Sea— The Prospect is beautiful— After returning I walked again upon the Quay, and saw a vessel under the Danish flag come in, from Charleston, South Carolina— I met on the Quay an Englishman named Kemble, who told me he had just arrived with a galliot; under the Russian flag, from London. She was in the Roads, and he had permission to unlade her to-morrow— She would return as soon as possible; perhaps on Monday; and if I did not conclude my bargain with the Danish Captain, he would readily give me passage, and land me and my family any where upon the Coast, where I should please. At the same time he said he wished not to interfere in the bargain with the Danish Captain whom he knew, and who was a good man— I am to see him again to-morrow Morning.

21. VI. Mr Campbell came this Morning, and renewed the proposal to me to take passage in his vessel— After breakfast I went on board the vessel, which is lying at the wharf— The Olga, Captain Köning of Riga— I agreed to take passage in her for thirty guineas including all my baggage— Met Mr Remsen, and went with him to Mr Russell’s, to make some arrangements for embarking our baggage— Mr Russell had a bad accident last Evening, by a fall in the Street by which he was severely bruised— Returning home I found the Danish Captain on the wharf near his ship, and told him I had procured a passage in another vessel. Mr Campbell came again afterwards, and said the Danish Captain was much offended at having lost us as passengers. He had been to my lodgings while I was out, and had told Mrs Adams that he would not take less than 150 franks for each person as passenger. After dinner I walked out on the quay with Mrs Adams— The weather has been the whole day very boisterous. In the Evening we went to a Séance Académique or Concert given by a Mr Moldetti an Italian who lodges at the same house with us— He was the only singer, accompanied by the Amateurs and Artists of the City—twelve or fourteen persons— The company was very small. Mr: Moldetti sung several Duos of two voices, and one quartetto, in four, the Tenor, Base, Counter and Treble, from behind a screen, all so different from each other that they might easily have been taken for the voices of four different persons— He also imitated the guittar, in great perfection, though in a ludicrous manner— The concert finished between ten and eleven O’Clock. I sent this day to a wine merchant recommended to me by Mr Russell, for a sample of Champagne wine, and determined to take a stock of that and other French wines, with me, to England.

22. VI:15. The Preparations for our departure occupied us the whole day—and we had until Evening the expectation of sailing this Night. I made a purchase of a small assortment of wines— The vessel had not unladen, till five in the afternoon, and was then two hours taking in ballast. The Custom house Officers made some difficulty about embarking the wines, after Sunset, until I produced my Passport from the Duke de Vicence, with which they were entirely satisfied. Mr Campbell is in dread of an Embargo, from one hour to another— My effects were all embarked by ten in the Evening; excepting only the cabin-baggage which we must take with us— I called upon Mr Russell before dinner; he has much recovered from his accident, and in the Evening came to see us— As did Mr Green, and Mr. Remsen.— The Danish ship, and several other vessels went out this Evening— The town of Havre which is entirely Royalist, has been put in a state of Siege, under martial Law, and this afternoon about thirty soldiers marched into it; which has highly exasperated the inhabitants— We are now notified to be ready to go on board the vessel at ten O’Clock to-morrow Morning.

23. V. At eleven O’Clock we embarked at the wharf on board of the Galliote Olga, of Riga, Captain Köning, and after some difficulties with the custom-house-Officers, we left the wharf just at Noon. Mr John Campbell, an Englishman, the owner of the Vessel, Mr Goddard, likewise an Englishman, but with a passport in which he appeared as a merchant of New-York, and Mr Remsen, were our fellow passengers. Mr Campbell had accidentally left part of his cloathing, and papers at his lodgings, and sent back for them, not being allowed after the vessel was from the wharf to land any person from it, without subjecting us to the necessity of a new clearance— After we were clear of the harbour, we lay to nearly two hours to wait for the return of the persons he had sent to recover his effects, but they had disappeared, and were not to be found. We came out of the Port with fine weather, but a scanty wind, and almost a calm— But early in the Evening the wind became fair for directing our course to Dover, and freshened to so strong a breeze, that the vessel though a dull Sailor went for some time nine knots an hour. My family were all very sick, and I was myself more nearly being so than I had been for upwards of twenty years— Our accommodations were quite indifferent. My wife and Charles had one birth in the Cabin— Lucie Hauel, the chamber-maid whom Mrs Adams took with her from Paris had another—and I lay on a small mattress lent me by Mr Campbell, thrown across the floor of the Cabin, with an old Great Coat, and the vessel’s flag for a covering.

24. IV. Mr Campbell came into the Cabin just before four O’Clock this morning, and told me that Dover Castle was in sight.— I had slept two or three hours, and lost the symptoms of approaching Sea-sickness— The Night was fine, and the swell, and wind had partly subsided— The motion of the vessel had been the more considerable, because she had not been sufficiently ballasted, and was too light— On going upon deck I saw very distinctly both the shores of France and England, and through the glass plainly discerned Dover Castle— The wind shortly after abated and a fog arose, which for some time intercepted the view of the Land on both sides— About six we were boarded by an officer from an English Gun-Brig, and at seven, a Dover Pilot came on board— The Captain went with his papers on shore in this boat, and we agreed with the Pilot that his men should come out with a larger boat, when we should be opposite to Dover Pier, to take us on shore with our baggage for half a guinea a person— The wind soon freshened again and the tide turned and drifted us so rapidly down, that we were obliged to lay to, the Pilot’s large boat still delaying to come out— The Custom-House it appears is open only at ten, and nothing could be done until the Officers were there.— The tide had already drifted us below the pier when the boat came out.— I left Antoine on board the vessel to take care of our effects and go to London with them; the rest of us with the baggage indispensible for immediate use landed in the boat. The wind was so strong and the surf so high, that we suffered some washing before we reached the canal within the pier— We landed at the Stairs just at 12 O’Clock having had a passage of 24 hours from Havre. Immediately on landing we were all required to go to the Custom-house; which my wife positively refused, and did not go. She went immediately to the York Hotel, kept by Payne. I went to the Custom-house, and submitted to the examination of my trunks— The Collector was not there. The Clerks told me they had received no order for the admission of my baggage— That the examination would be only a formality; but that there had been only one instance of exemption from it, which was last year for the Emperor of Russia, and the king of Prussia. That it was very probable they would find nothing in my trunks liable to be taken— I told them it was very probable they would find such Articles and must use them at their pleasure— They examined the trunks, and found or chose to find nothing to take— Mr Campbell and Mr Goddard determined to take a Post-Chaise, and go immediately for London. Mr Remsen wished to go with them; but being an American it was insisted that he must wait three days until a Passport could be obtained
for him for from London, the regulations of the alien law having recently been put in force anew against foreigners. I had a Passport from Lord Castlereagh for myself, my family and suite; and I authorized Mr Remsen to go immediately to London, as a person of my Suite— The Officers after making some difficulties assented to this, and Mr Remsen accordingly went. They left Dover at 2 O’Clock P.M— Mrs Adams being much fatigued, preferred waiting until to-morrow Morning. I wrote to Mr Beasley, requesting him to inform me, by a line to be left at the Green Man, Blackheath, if he had taken lodgings for me, as I some time since desired him to do— We spent the remainder of the day at Dover, and walked two or three times round the City— Mrs Adams was excessively fatigued, and in the Evening very unwell. Mr Payne, the keeper of the York Hotel, recollected my father and mother and Coll. Smith and my Sister, who he said had all repeatedly lodged at his house. I remembered having once been there myself in August 1784.
25. V. London. We breakfasted this morning at six, and at Seven left Dover with two Post-Chaises, Mrs. Adams and myself in one—Lucy and Charles in the other.

p.hi: Itinerary of the Journey from Dover to London.

div.p:
The expence of traveling in this manner is about the same as in France— There however I had the additional charge, and trouble of a Carriage. In England the charge is the same, whether they furnish you Carriages or only Horses—one shilling and six pence a mile for a Post Chaise and pair, and the same for the horses alone. From three to four Shillings to each driver, a shilling to the hostler, and between 2 and 4 Shillings for Turnpikes are paid at each Stage. The expences of traveling by Post have exactly doubled since I first knew them in 1778. and in England they have also doubled since I first knew them in 1783. The expences at Inns upon the road, and almost all others in England are nearly double what they are in France— The face of the Country from Dover to London was quite familiar to me— I had travelled the whole way twice, and the greater part of it, many times. Although eighteen years have elapsed since I was last in England, its outward appearance remains much the same, and the ride from Dover to London is one of those which present the Country in its most favourable light.— We met on the road a regiment of soldiers marching to Dover, to embark for Flanders; many beggars, and families of apparent paupers wandering about the Country without shed or shelter— The Cities have all the show of prosperity, but with an extraordinary proportion of Cards upon the houses advertising them for sale. We did not stop on the road to dine, but took at Dartford, each a Sandwich and a glass of ale.— When we alighted at the Inn, there for that purpose, a man came in to the chamber where we were, stating himself to be a revenue Officer, charged to detect the smuggling of silks and laces, and observing that there was a Portmanteau Trunk in the Chaise in which I had arrived— I told him I had come to this Country in the character of a public Minister, and therefore not subject to the operation of the revenue Laws— He said he could not know that— I replied that I would shew it to him, and took from my pocket Lord Castlereagh’s Passport.— He did not look at it, but made an awkward apology for having intruded upon me, and withdrew in some confusion— We stopp’d at the Green-Man, Blackheath at the six Mile Stone, and found there Mr Williams one of Mr Beasley’s Clerks, with a Letter from him, informing me that he had taken lodgings for me, at N. 67 Harley-Street, Cavendish Square, and that we should find there our two eldest Sons, George and John, who had just arrived from America— Mr Beasley added that he lived in the same Street, and invited us to dine with him at half past six O’Clock— It was seven however when we received the Note, and eight when we arrived at our lodgings in London. We found our dear sons whom we had not seen for nearly six years— George grown almost out of our knowledge—John yet small for his age. Mr Saml: G. Perkins, in whose care they came from America, and Mr Todd were at the door when we alighted, and promised to call to-morrow Morning— Mr Beasley, shortly afterwards came in— Mr Crawford had left the same lodgings last Monday, and our
sons came into them the next day. Mr Gallatin and Mr Clay, as I expected, are in London— Mr Bayard, at Plymouth, on board the Neptune; and so ill that he cannot be landed— Mrs Adams was so much overcome by the fatigue of the Journey, following so immediately upon the Sea-sickness of the Voyage, and by the agitation of meeting so unexpectedly her long absent children, that she was obliged to retire, and twice fainted— She was relieved by a warm bath. There are public baths in the house where we lodge— My Sons gave me many Letters from my father, mother, and other friends, which engaged me until after Midnight.

26. VII: Mrs Adams, though yet much fatigued after the Journey found herself this day quite recovered from her illness— Mr Beasley called upon me this Morning, and promised to make the necessary applications for the admission of that part of our baggage which came in the Olga; which has not yet arrived— As the dispatches from the Government of the United States, with my Commission were deposited in the hands of Messrs: Baring, I first went to the house of Mr Alexander Baring, for whom I had a Letter from Mr D. Parker.— He resides in Portman Square— I found him at home, but the papers for me were at the Compting House in Bishopsgate within—in the City. I paid visits to Mr Clay and Mr Gallatin, the latter of whom was not at home. Mr Clay mentioned to me the state of the Negotiation which Mr Gallatin and he have commenced here in relation to Commerce.— I then went into the City to the Compting house of Messrs Baring, and received from Mr Alexander Baring the Dispatches from America enclosing my Commission as Envoy Extraordinary and Minister Plenipotentiary at the Court of Great-Britain, with a Letter of Recredence to the Emperor of Russia, a Letter of Credence to the British Prince Regent, Instructions, a Copy of which I had already received at Paris, a Letter of Credit upon Messrs: Baring for 25000 dollars, and a Letter respecting my compensation which places me in a state of suspense and perplexity greater then I have been in heretofore— I called then upon Mr S. Williams 13. Finsbury Square, to whose care all my baggage was directed.— I returned home about 5 O’Clock in the afternoon and we received a visit from Mr and Mrs: Beasley— While I was out Messrs: Perkins, Todd, Everett, and Joy had paid visits— We dined at six— Mr Joy came again in the Evening, and sat with us, until near Midnight— I wrote a Note to Lord Castlereagh informing him of my arrival with a public Commission, and requesting him to appoint a time for me to call upon him.

27. VII:30. I went and delivered the Letters to the Duke of Sorentino and to Mr Douglas Kinnaird, which I had received from them—and at the same time left Cards— The day was absorbed in paying and receiving visits, and in the confusion of arrangements for accommodation at our lodgings— Mr Beasley has engaged them at £8 Sterling a week including the table and household furniture provided for us, by Mr Mills the tenant of the house.— We have engaged a woman Cook, a Housemaid, a footman, and a Coachman. The footman, as yet, by the day. We have applications from a multitude of tradesmen of all descriptions, for employment, and from a multitude of Servants of all kinds, wanting situations. With Mrs Adams I returned the visit of Mr and Mrs: Beasley, and I received yesterday and this day many Letters; some of them requiring Answers, which I have at present no possible time for writing— Mr Clay and Mr Gallatin, Mr and Mrs Gore, Mr and Mrs Trumbull, Mr & Miss Haven and Mr Ashton paid us visits— Lieutt: Newcomb wrote me a note mentioning his intention to go next Tuesday for Paris— Lord Castlereagh answered my Note, and appointed next Monday Morning at eleven O’Clock to receive me; and Mr Campbell wrote to inform me that the Olga had arrived at her Moorings.

28. VI:30. I received visits from the Duke of Sorentino, Marquis of Salinas, to whom Mr Erving had given me a Letter, and from Mr Douglas Kinnaird to whom I had brought a Letter from his brother Lord Kinnaird, at Paris— He invited me to dine with him next Tuesday, at a quarter before seven— The usual dining hour at this end of the town is Seven— It being Sunday, nothing could be done to obtain our baggage from the vessel—Antoine came up from it, and returned to take care of our effects. Mr Gallatin called upon me, and I shewed him the dispatch which I have received from the Secretary of the Treasury— He put into my hands the papers he had drawn up as a projet for a Treaty of Commerce— A Mr James Brown an Englishman formerly an Editor of the Newspaper called the Statesman, and of the Naval Chronicle wrote me, the day after my arrival here and requested an interview with me— He came the next Morning and had a long Conversation with me— He had a proposal from a Lieutenant in the British Navy, who was desirous of resigning that situation and entering into the service of the United States— He said there were seven Post Captains known to him, who had the same wish, and such a multitude of Officers of all the ranks below that, as would alone supply the Officers for a considerable navy. I told Mr Brown that I had no authority to engage any naval Officer in the service of the United States— As they and Great-Britain were at Peace, I saw no insuperable objection to the admission of a British Officer duly discharged from the English service, into that of the United States; but it might not be agreeable to the Government of this Country, and it was my duty to avoid every thing which might tend to give dissatisfaction to the British Government, in my relations with it. I also stated in a forcible manner the difficulties which a foreign officer must overcome, to obtain admission into our service— Mr Brown then intimated to me his own desire to go and settle in America himself which I did not encourage, and finally he expressed an intention to publish a periodical paper, relating principally to American affairs, and calculated to spread more correct American information than now prevails. He asked me if I would in that case favour him by the Communication of American Papers.— I promised
him that I would, if the character of the publication should be such as he described, and contain nothing which could justly give umbrage to the British Government. He said that his principles were those of moderation, but he had been displaced as Editor of the Naval Chronicle for some of his publications, and had given offence by his earnestness against the forging of American ship papers— He sent me a Letter written to him by Mr Perceval’s orders on this subject, and the minutes of a conversation which he had with Mr Perceval relating to it— He also told me that in the year 1807. Mr Canning had proposed to him to go to America, and there publish a Newspaper in support of the British Government, and to promote its influence. I have given this person no encouragement; but he says that the business of forging Ships papers is reviving, and that Van Sander has now orders for papers for upwards of forty vessels— Mr Beasley gave me the evidence respecting the transactions at Dartmoor Prison; part of which I read— This Evening I took a long walk with George into the City.

29. VI. Lord Castlereagh had appointed eleven O’Clock this morning, for me to see him at his house, in St: James’s Square— After waiting nearly an hour beyond that time for my Carriage, I took a Hackney Coach and went there— The Duke of Orleans was with him, and I waited about another half hour before he received me. I gave him a copy of my Letter of Credence to the Prince Regent, upon which he said that he would take the Orders of His Royal Highness as to the time when he would receive it. There was some general Conversation upon the subject of the concerns mutually interesting to the two Nations. I assured him of the disposition on the part of the American Government to perform with the utmost fidelity all their engagements contracted in the late Treaty of Peace, and to adopt every other measure calculated to consolidate the friendship, and to promote the Harmony between the two Countries— As a token of which An Act of Congress had passed previous to the close of their late Session tendering on the part of the United States a reciprocal abolition of all discriminating duties of Tonnage and upon merchandize imported in our own or in British Vessels— I presumed he was in possession of a copy of that act— He said he believed they were; but he would thank me for a sight of it—and I promised to furnish him with a copy. I mentioned also the Message of the President, recommending the exclusion of foreign Seamen, not already naturalized, from the naval and merchant service of the United States—a measure which Congress owing to the shortness of time had not acted upon, but which would probably be hereafter adopted.— He said that what had been done by the Government of the United States in this respect had given the greater satisfaction here, as an opinion, probably erroneous, had heretofore prevailed that the American Government encouraged and invited foreign Seamen— That as to the principle he was afraid there was little prospect of a possibility of coming to an agreement, as we adhered to the right of naturalization for which we contended, and as no Government here could possibly abandon the right to the allegiance of British Subjects— I said that I saw no better prospect than he did of an agreement upon the principle— But it was not the disposition of the American Government or Nation to apply the force of arms to the maintenance of any abstract principle— The number of British Seamen, naturalized in America was so small that it could be no object of concern to this Government. If British subjects were excluded for the future, there could be no motive for taking men from American Vessels— If the practice totally ceased, we should never call upon the British Government for any sacrifice of their principle— When the evil ceased to be felt we should readily deem it to have ceased to exist— He said that there would be every disposition to guard against the possibility of abuse, and the Admiralty was now occupied in prescribing regulations for the naval Officers which he hoped would prevent all cause of complaint on the part of the United States. He then mentioned the late unfortunate occurrence at Dartmoor Prison, and the measures which had been taken by agreement between him and Messrs: Clay and Gallatin, on that occasion— I said I had received a copy of the Report made by Mr King and Mr Larpent, after their examination into the transaction; and of the written depositions which had been taken, as well on that examination as previously at the Coroner’s Inquest— That after what had been done, I considered the procedure as so far terminated that I was not aware of any further step to be taken by me, until I should receive the Instructions of my Government on the case; the Evidence was so voluminous, and I had so lately received it, that I had not yet entirely read it through; but from the general impression upon my mind made by what I had read, I regretted that a regular trial of Captain Shortland had not been ordered, and I thought it probable that such would be the opinion of my Government. He said that undoubtedly there were cases in which a trial was the best remedy that could be resorted to; but there were others in which it was the worst— That a trial the result of which should be an acquittal, would place the whole affair in a more unpleasant situation than it would be without it— That the evidence was extremely contradictory— That it had been found impossible to trace to any individual the most unjustifiable part of the firing, and that Captain Shortland denied having given the order to fire— I admitted that the Evidence was contradictory; but said that from the impression of the whole mass of it upon me, I could not doubt, either that Captain Shortland gave the order to fire, or that under the Circumstances of the case, it was unnecessary. It was true, the result of a
trial might be an acquittal, but as it was the regular remedy for a case of this description, the substitution of any other was susceptible of strong objections, and left the officer apparently justified, when I could not but think them altogether unjustifiable. I then mentioned the earnest desire of the American Government for the full execution of the Stipulations in the Treaty of Ghent and that my Instructions had expressed the hope of an appointment as soon as possible of the Commissioners on the part of this Country, for proceeding to the settlement of the boundary line— Lord Castlereagh asked what would be the most convenient Season of the year for transacting the business— I said I believed it might be done at any Season— But as the line would be in a high Northern Latitude, the Summer Season would probably be most for the personal convenience of the Commissioners. He said the appointments would be made with reference to that Consideration— I then observed that the British Admiral stationed in the Chesapeak had declined resorting Slaves that he had taken, under a Construction of the first Article of the Treaty which my Government considered erroneous, and which I presumed this Government would likewise so consider. That a reference to the original draft of the British Projet, and to an alteration proposed by us and assented to by the British Commissioners would immediately shew the incorrectness of this Construction— He said it would be best to refer this matter to the Gentlemen who were authorized to confer with us on the subject of a Treaty of Commerce.— He asked if Mr Gallatin and Mr Clay had communicated to me, what had passed between them and this Government, on this head— I said they had— He asked if I was joined to them in that business— I said I was, but that it was altogether distinct from my Mission to this Court— He said the same persons had been appointed to treat with us, who had concluded with us the Treaty of Ghent, and Mr Robinson the Vice-President of the Board of Trade had been added to them— They had already had some conferences with Messrs: Clay and Gallatin, and their Powers were now made out and ready for them to proceed in the Negotiation— I asked Lord Castlereagh if he could mention to me the time when the Prince Regent would receive my Credential Letter— He said if I was desirous of presenting it, at an early day the Prince would receive me at a private Audience— Otherwise it would be at the first Levee day.— I said that would suit me perfectly well, and I would not wish to give his Royal Highness that trouble of assigning a particular day for a private audience. He then asked me if I had not come last from France; and what there was there of New— I told him they were assembling there, all the force that they could collect, and it would be a very considerable force— He said that was to be expected— He asked if I had seen any of the fortifications erecting at Paris— I said I had seen what was doing at Montmartre; and thought very little of it— The object I believed was rather to employ workmen, than to defend the City— He said it was ridiculous to pretend defending the City— It could not be defended. If Montmartre could be defended, there were other avenues equally accessible. I did not incline to converse much with him upon French Affairs, and therefore took leave— His Deportment is sufficiently graceful, and his person is handsome— His manner was cold, but not absolutely repulsive— After returning home I went and paid a visit to Count Lieven the Russian Ambassador, who resides in the neighbourhood of our lodgings— I told him I had received a Letter of Recredence, from the President of the United States, addressed to the Emperor of Russia— That Mr Bayard had been appointed as my successor at his Court, and if his state of health had been such as to permit him to proceed to Russia, or to the place of the Emperor’s abode, I should have made him the bearer of it— But Mr Bayard was very ill, and intended to return to the United States— I came therefore to consult him the Count, and ask him what would be my best method of transmitting the Letter to the Emperor— Whether I should deliver it to him; or address it to the place where the Emperor may be; or transmit it to the Department of Foreign Affairs at St: Petersburg.— The Count said he would write and take the Emperors orders on the Subject— He asked me whether Mr Bayard was really so ill, or whether it was only a reluctance at going to Russia— I assured him that it was a real and so severe an illness that it was even doubtful whether he could recover from it— I had then much Conversation with the Count on the present state of France, and the prospects of the new War. He thinks that Buonaparte (for so he must be called here) has not, and cannot assemble more than two hundred thousand Men of regular troops, and I am of the same opinion— I gave him, such information of the state of France as I think correct, and he said it agreed with all the best information that had been collected from that Country.— He told me the Emperor Alexander was to leave Vienna the 23d: of this Month and was probably now at Munich— On my return home I had a visit from Mr Clay— He said that Mr Gallatin and he had invitations to dine next Thursday with Earl Grey— That there had also been an invitation to Mr Crawford, but he was gone, and he Mr Clay had now a note from Sir James Mackintosh, through whom the invitations had been given, mentioning that Lord Grey, having
heard of my arrival wished me also to be of the company— I accepted the invitation— Mr Clay told me he had also an invitation at Countess Grey’s, to an Evening party to-morrow.— I dined with Mrs Adams at Mr Beasley’s.— Mr Robertson late a Member of Congress from New-Orleans, Lieutenant Newcomb, Mr Everett, and some other Gentlemen were of the party. Mrs: Beasley is a French Lady, of Bordeaux, and her family is of the Royalist party— Her brother came with the Duchess d’Angouleme to this Country and dined with us— There is no conversation upon any other topic than France, and it is scarcely possible to talk in any way upon it without immediately shocking Passions and Prejudices— I found it strongly by experience yesterday and this day.— The Ladies withdrew after dinner, and the Gentlemen sat at table about half an hour longer— This practice still continues here; but the dining hour is so late that the men cannot sit long, unless they pass the Night at table— We came home about eleven, and I found a Card, of Countess Grey, “at Home, Tuesday, 30th. May.” The Card had my name on the top— This is the fashion of invitation to Evening parties without dancing or Cards.

30. VIII. I wrote this Morning a Note to Lord Castlereagh, enclosing Copies of the Act of Congress concerning the discriminating duties, and the Message of the President, recommending a Law to secure the Navigation of American Vessels exclusively by American Seamen. Wrote also a Letter of Introduction for Mr Newcomb to Mr Jackson, the Charge d’Affairs at Paris. I had visits from him, from Mr Murdoch, Mr Hubbard, and Mr Snow, who brought me a letter of Introduction from Mr Crawford— I paid visits to Mr Gallatin and Mr Clay, and dined with Mr Douglas Kinnaird N. 32 Clarges Street— The invitation was for a quarter before seven— The Clock had struck seven when I left my lodgings, and I was the first person at the house, and waited about a quarter of an hour before Mr and Mrs Kinnaird made their appearance— The Earl of Roseberry, Lord Forbes, General Fergusson, Mr Fazakerley, Mr Lamb, and some other Gentlemen were there.— The Conversation was almost entirely about France— Several of the Gentlemen were members of the House of Commons, and had paired off until ten O’Clock to come and dine— There was debate in the House, upon some Catholic question. Mr Fazakerley had seen Napoleon at the Island of Elba. Mr Kinnaird related many anecdotes of an Irishman named Macnamara, who had also been to Elba, and told foolish stories of his conversations with Napoleon. He also spoke with great Indignation against Lord Cathcart, who caused the imprisonment of a Mr Semple for eleven weeks in the fortress of Silberberg.— Mrs Kinnaird is a violent Anti-Bonapartist— We sat a short time at table, after Mrs Kinnaird had withdrawn— It was near eleven when I left the house and went to Countess Grey’s— Very few of the company had assembled— The Earl received me with much politeness and introduced me to his Lady— The company shortly afterwards came in crowds— I was introduced to the Duke of Gloucester, Earl Fitzwilliam, Lady Mackintosh, Mr Rogers the Poet, and a Mr Sharpe, who told me that he had formerly known my father, when he was here— There was neither dancing, nor Card playing; but there were assembled about 300 persons, who filled two chambers, and passed a couple of hours in looking at one another and occasional conversation among their respective acquaintances— The Duke of Gloucester asked me several questions, about America, and the American Ministers who had formerly been here— Lord Erskine predicted the immediate downfall of Buonaparte.— It was about one in the Morning when I came home.

31. VIII. I received between ten and eleven this Morning Mr Kinnaird’s packets and immediately took them to Mr Newcomb’s lodgings at Richards’s Coffee House, N. 8 Fleet Street.— He and Mr Robertson had left town about an hour before— I then went to the St: Paul’s Coffee-House, to enquire for Mr Beck, who was going to Plymouth, and by whom I wished to send the Letters which I had received at Paris for Mr Crawford— He had also gone off early this morning. Mr Beasley afterwards called upon me and was sending a packet to Dover to overtake Mr Robertson there— I gave him the packets which I had intended to send by Mr Newcomb, requesting him to forward them with his own. We received Visits from Count Lieven, Mr and Miss Bayard, Messrs: Remsen, Ogden, Pitcairn, Rogers, and Shaw— They left no time for occupation.

Day. The first half of this Month we spent at Paris, much like that which preceeded it— The next ten days we were upon our Journey and Voyage— The last week, we have spent at London, in a hurly burly of confusion. We are so straightened for Room at our lodgings, that I have not a chamber to use as my Cabinet or writing room— I have no Secretary— The Visits received and visits to be paid engross great part of my time—the Domestic Arrangements, looking out for a house, for Servants, a Carriage and horses, and for our baggage and effects which are not yet landed from the vessel, absorb the rest— The Commercial Treaty, the Affair of the Prisoners at Dartmoor, applications for Passports, and starving American Sailors are all assailing me at the same time, and I receive about ten letters every day, scarcely one of which I am able to answer— I shall be able to bring nothing into order, until we get settled in a house, where I can have a writing chamber.
